name: Helen Kroll Kramer
biography:
Helen Kramer Kroll is best known for her handwoven upholstery and drapery for interiors. In the 1930s, she attended the Traphagen School of Design in New York, focusing on costume design. Upon graduating, she traveled throughout Europe to hone her skills for fabric design. Kramer returned to New York City and opened a small shop on E 54th Street, and began to receive many commissions. To meet the growing demand for her handwoven textiles, Kroll opened a showroom on Madison Avenue in New York with her brother, Boris. They named their firm Cromwell. 
During the early 1940s and in the midst of WWII, she accompanied her husband, a doctor, to the Ashford General Hospital in White Sulphur Springs, West Virginia. She volunteered and established a weaving department and began to train occupational therapists to teach weaving. The program was a success not only recreationally, but improved patients with physical injuries, as well as a soothing pastime for those who were experiencing mental difficulty.
Kroll was intensely interested in color and the ways in which textiles could be vehicles of expression like paintings in modern art. Kroll is also credited with utilizing the “swatch card” for interior decorators, which greatly expedited the design and approval process. By 1955, Kroll worked primarily as a textile design consultant, but did pursue a more personal artistic expression within tapestry weaving.
